channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: White House Student Loan Forgiveness Could Cost About $400 Billion
item.description: The estimate by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office gauged the cost over 30 years, though the bulk of the effects to the economy would be felt over the next decade.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

item.title: NASA Smashes Into an Asteroid, Completing a Mission to Save a Future Day
item.description: The DART spacecraft completed its 10-month journey to demonstrate a technique that could defend the planet from deadly space rocks in the future.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.category: Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory
item.media:description: The asteroid Dimorphos 11 seconds before NASA’s DART spacecraft collided with it on Monday.

item.title: Strong Dollar Is Good for the US but Bad for the World
item.description: The Federal Reserve may have no choice but to wage a relentless inflation fight, but countries rich and poor are feeling the pain of plunging currencies.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: When it comes to global finance and trade, the United States has outsize influence.

item.title: S&P 500 Hits Lowest Level of 2022 as Global Sell-off Continues
item.description: The drop to the new low, after stocks staged a brief recovery this summer, shows how uncertain the environment for investors has become.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Simonetti

item.title: Two Cities, Two Armies: Pivot Points in the Fight in Ukraine’s East
item.description: The battle for the critical Donbas region in Ukraine is centered on two strategically important cities: Lyman, held by the Russians, and Bakhmut, held by Ukraine. The fighting over the cities is fierce as both armies race to claim new ground.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks

item.title: Russia Admits to Draft Problems as Anger Flares Into Violence
item.description: The Kremlin’s spokesman tried to shift blame for errors in the call-up to regional agencies on Monday, the same day a gunman attacked a draft office in Siberia.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Shashank Bengali and Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: Reservists from Tara, in the Omsk region of Siberia, at a recruitment office on Monday.

item.title: Women in Iran Take Center Stage in Antigovernment Protests
item.description: Women have been casting off their legally required head scarves, forming the primary image of the protests. But grievances against a repressive regime go far beyond the hijab.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Women have been at the center of protests like this one last week in Tehran, defying the mandate to wear head scarves.

item.title: 4 Years After Thrilling Cave Rescue, Sleepy Park Readies for Onslaught
item.description: An unheralded national park in Thailand was the center of global attention when 12 boys were trapped in a cave there. In the wake of major movies about the rescue, the park expects a visitor surge.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Luke Duggleby for The New York Times
item.media:description: The entrance to the Tham Luang Cave in Chiang Rai province, Thailand, last month. The rescue of 12 boys and their soccer coach trapped in the cave in 2018 has since become the focus of documentary films and Hollywood blockbusters.

item.title: More Trans Teens Are Choosing ‘Top Surgery’
item.description: Small studies suggest that breast removal surgery improves transgender teenagers’ well-being, but data is sparse. Some state leaders oppose such procedures for minors.
item.dc:creator: Azeen Ghorayshi
item.category: World Professional Association for Transgender Health
item.media:credit: Eva Marie Uzcategui for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Sidhbh Gallagher’s unusual embrace of social media platforms like TikTok has made her one of the most visible surgeons in her field.

item.title: Hurricane Ian’s Uncertain Path Keeps Much of Florida on Alert
item.description: The authorities urged residents to begin evacuating some low-lying areas of the Gulf Coast. A troubling combination of dangerous storm surges, flooding and powerful winds is predicted for the coming days.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Parker, Alexandra Glorioso and Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Staff members of Doc’s Beach House, a restaurant in Bonita Springs, Fla., filled sandbags to help protect the property against Hurricane Ian.

item.title: G.O.P. Redoubles Efforts to Tie Democrats to High Crime Rates
item.description: With images of lawlessness, G.O.P. candidates are pressing the issue in places where worries about public safety are omnipresent. Democrats, on the defensive, are promising to fund the police.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Jonathan Weisman
item.media:description: Police officers in Gresham, Ore., a Portland suburb, in July. Worries about crime and homelessness are widespread in Portland and other cities Republicans are highlighting in political messaging.

item.title: Doug Mastriano’s Sputtering Campaign: No TV Ads, Tiny Crowds, Little Money
item.description: As he runs for governor of Pennsylvania, Doug Mastriano is being heavily outspent by his Democratic rival and trails badly in polling. National Republicans show little desire to help him.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times
item.media:description: Doug Mastriano spoke to a few dozen supporters on Saturday in front of the State Capitol in Harrisburg, Pa. Days before, his running mate, Carrie Lewis DelRosso, had urged supporters to attend “the big rally.”

item.title: Six-Figure Artworks, by a Fifth Grader
item.description: Andres Valencia’s paintings have sold for more than $125,000. And he’s 10 years old.
item.dc:creator: Alex Hawgood
item.media:credit: Elliott Jerome Brown Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andres Valencia at the Chase Contemporary Gallery in SoHo, where his art was exhibited this summer.

item.title: Trump’s Heartless QAnon Embrace
item.description: He’s reinforcing life-ruining delusions.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg

item.title: Russians Are Terrified, and Have Nowhere to Turn
item.description: For citizens who want to escape conscription, there simply aren’t many options.
item.dc:creator: Ilia Krasilshchik
item.media:description: Conscripted Russian men attending a farewell ceremony in Bataysk, Russia, on Monday.

item.title: The Dangers of Election-Denying Secretary of State Campaigns
item.description: Republican Dominic Rapini is unlikely to become Connecticut’s secretary of state, but election-denying candidacies like his are still damaging.
item.dc:creator: Chris Geidner

item.title: Why Zombie Reaganomics Still Rules the G.O.P.
item.description: MAGA is in charge, but policy caters to the wealthy.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman

item.title: Biden’s Student Loan Plan Has Issues
item.description: Its income-driven component could backfire.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by CSA Images via Getty Images

item.title: Biden’s Cautious Foreign Policy Is Imperiling the United States
item.description: We have let Russian threats determine our actions, which encourages Russia and others to test our resolve.
item.dc:creator: Kori Schake
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Biden after delivering remarks at the United Nations General Assembly on Wednesday.

item.title: Where Are All Our Post-Covid Patients?
item.description: Post-Covid care has become a luxury.
item.dc:creator: Daniela J. Lamas

item.title: Why Candidates Owe Voters Full Medical Transparency
item.description: Health doesn’t have to be so political.
item.dc:creator: Lawrence K. Altman
item.media:credit: Kriston Jae Bethel/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Lt. Gov. John Fetterman of Pennsylvania greets supporters following a Senate campaign rally.

item.title: A Doctor Burns Out: The Week in Narrated Articles
item.description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.

item.title: The World Cup Is a Feeling, One That Money Can’t Buy
item.description: The tournament is, at heart, a feeling, and FIFA and Qatar may be forgetting that no amount of spending is a substitute.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: What happens when the World Cup is built for selfies, not supporters?

item.title: The Republic
item.description: American democracy is under threat. But for some candidates and voters, democracy isn’t even the destination anymore.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Run-Up’ Team
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times. Photo by Travis Dove for The New York Times

item.title: Are Your Patients Worried About the Polio Vaccine?
item.description: We want to hear from you.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Gabler and Sheera Frenkel

item.title: Trump White House Called Capitol Rioter on Jan. 6, Book Says
item.description: Denver Riggleman, a former staff member of the House committee investigating the assault on the Capitol, said the call came from a White House landline.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: The release of the book by a former staff member for the House Jan. 6 committee has frustrated and angered some committee members — and sparked a public dispute.

item.title: Italy’s Hard-Right Lurch Raises New Concerns in Washington
item.description: The Biden administration pledged to work with the country’s new leaders despite worries. Several Republicans hailed the Italian election results.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: In the near term, the political success of Giorgia Meloni and her nationalist Brothers of Italy party is unlikely to rupture relations between Washington and Rome.

item.title: Biogen Agrees to Pay $900 Million to Settle Lawsuit Over Kickbacks
item.description: The company was accused of illegally paying doctors to prescribe its drugs over those of its rivals.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley
item.media:description: The case began a decade ago, when a Biogen employee filed a whistle-blower lawsuit against the company.

item.title: Federal Government’s $20 Billion Embrace of ‘Climate Smart’ Farming
item.description: The techniques are a cornerstone of the Agriculture Department’s approach to addressing a warming planet, but it is unclear whether more widespread deployment of such methods can truly reverse the effects of climate change.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.media:credit: Andrew Spear for The New York Times
item.media:description: Herds on Lindsay Klaunig’s farm outside Athens, Ohio, are rotated to allow vegetation to regrow.

item.title: UTI Treatment: What to Know About Supplements and Prevention
item.description: More than half of American women will have a urinary tract infection during their lives. But can supplements really stave that off?
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: Know Your Uterus
item.description: Endometriosis, fibroid tumors and structural anomalies are just a few conditions that can impact uterine health.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Hobson

item.title: Postpartum Body Changes You Should Know About
item.description: From separated abs to pelvic floor issues, what to look out for after having a baby.
item.dc:creator: Anna Nowogrodzki

item.title: This Chemical Can Impair Fertility, but It’s Hard to Avoid
item.description: Hormone-disrupting phthalates can be found in everything from plastics and household goods to personal care products. Studies have shown they may be harmful to women’s reproductive systems.
item.dc:creator: Liza Gross

item.title: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome: What It Is, How to Manage It
item.description: Often misunderstood and misdiagnosed, PCOS can play havoc with your fertility. Here’s how to recognize the symptoms and take action to protect your reproductive health.
item.dc:creator: Hilda Hutcherson

item.title: In ‘The Furrows,’ Namwali Serpell Confronts a Sibling’s Disappearance
item.description: Confronting sudden loss in her own life, Namwali Serpell has written “The Furrows,” a disquieting portrait of the human mind, warped by grief.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Christensen
item.media:credit: Nate Palmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: “When my sister died, it was just a total chaos,” Namwali Serpell said. When her mother died, the family “understood what needed to be done.”

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
